content.title: Case Study: Governance Framework for Just Energy Transitions in Nigeria

content.text: However, governance gaps have emerged in the implementation of this plan, including: Fragmented leadership and weak institutional coordination, with ministries and agencies working in silos; Conflicting policies that undermine long-term transition goals; Limited public participation and transparency, with minimal influence from local communities, civil society, and marginalized groups; Weak regulatory oversight, allowing vested economic and political interests to shape energy decisions with limited accountability. To understand these challenges more systematically, the UNDP applied a conceptual governance framework to assess Nigeria’s energy transition. Before diving into the specific governance issues, we first explore the elements of this framework.

A conceptual framework To analyze how countries govern their energy transitions, the UNDP developed a conceptual framework that integrates governance principles with key elements of energy transition. The framework seeks to answer two critical questions: 1. How do countries use governance mechanisms to manage their energy transitions? (Governance needs) 2. How do energy transitions reshape governance structures? (Governance implications)

This framework is structured as a matrix (See the next page), combining the four focus areas discussed earlier (X-axis) and Four Elements of Energy Transition (Y-Axis). These represent the key areas where governance plays a role in energy transitions: • Political Vision & Commitment – Establishing long-term strategies and leadership for the transition. • Financial Capital & Investment – Mobilizing clean energy financing and ensuring financial transparency. • System Infrastructure & Innovation – Expanding renewable energy grids, technologies, and innovation. • Social Impacts & Equity – Managing job losses, reskilling, and social protection in the transition

Each intersection in the matrix highlights a guiding question that helps assess the governance needs and implications for a fair energy transition. By mapping these governance principles to energy transition elements, the framework helps identify gaps, risks, and opportunities in how a country manages its just energy transition.

To evaluate the effectiveness of the Just Energy Transition Governance Framework, the application of this conceptual framework was tested its application in Nigeria. Note: It is important to note that the below content is not yet a case study but simply paraphrases and summarizes contributions that were shared by participants of the initial group conversations in Nigeria. These contributions are not analyzed or contextualized and represent the views of the individual interlocutors. The purpose of sharing this ‘raw material’ is to illustrate what discussions the conceptual framework proposed here can trigger.

The objective was to assess how governance mechanisms influence Nigeria’s energy transition policies, identify key challenges, and gather insights for refining the framework before applying it to other case studies.

The research team used a two-step approach: 1. Desk research: Reviewing Nigeria’s energy transition policies, governance structures, and socio-economic context. 2. Stakeholder consultations: Engaging 29 stakeholders from government, civil society, academia, industry, and international organizations to validate the framework’s relevance.
The research team then mapped the findings onto the framework to create heat map below highlighting the most frequently discussed governance challenge.

The application of the Just Energy Transition Governance Framework in Nigeria revealed critical governance gaps affecting the country’s energy transition. The most frequently discussed challenge was Political Vision & Commitment, with stakeholders highlighting institutional fragmentation, weak policy coordination, and short-term political decision-making as major barriers. Legal and regulatory inconsistencies—such as conflicting fossil fuel and renewable energy policies—also emerged as significant concerns. Civic engagement and transparency remain weak, with minimal inclusion of local communities, women, and marginalized groups in shaping Nigeria’s Energy Transition Plan (ETP). Stakeholders also noted power imbalances in land ownership and resource control, which could impact equitable access to energy transition benefits. Financial governance was less discussed, but concerns were raised about rushed investments in critical minerals, lack of transparency in climate finance, and limited awareness of carbon markets. content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

cards.title: Energy governance comprises the mechanisms, processes, policies, and institutions through which governments, people, communities, and corporations articulate their interests, exercise their legal rights, meet their obligations, and mediate their differences in relation to energy.

Governance systems must prioritize integrity, transparency, and independent oversight to build trust and ensure responsible decision-making. Mechanisms like independent audits and regulatory agencies are essential to evaluate and uphold accountability during energy transitions.
A just energy transition prioritieses Inclusive and effective institutions, legal and regulatory frameworks, civic engagement and empowerment and appropriate and independent oversight.
